Exactly right.  For some reason, he frequently omits the /h part of the RHS.  Even in his book, it's presented at the end of this section almost as an afterthought, yet you can never get the discrete solution to match the continuous one if you don't recognize this.
@davidlovell729  is there an explanation of why the RHS is divided by h in the book? I worked the example in the video through and was out by a factor of h

For the continuous problem, e^(a+bi)t can be factored into e^at x e^(bi)t.  e^(bi)t is a sinusoid.  It oscillates steadily, forever.  The only thing interesting about it is its frequency and phase.  If a>0, then e^at grows and grows, so the product grows and grows; e.g. the oscillations get larger and larger.  If a=0, then the answer is the sinusoid itself.  If a<0, then e^at is always decreasing, so the product is always decreasing, so the oscillations get smaller and smaller.  He explains the discrete case quite clearly.
Modulus is correct. When you exponentiate a complex number, the e^(real part) becomes modulus. Eg 3+4i modulus is 5 but for e^(3+4i) modulus is e^3

you should look at the real columns displacements. if you load a column (real column made of steel) at some height the displasement differs as the greens functions. Factor of 1/5 for inverse of K is also make sense. Just draw the graphs of green functions and figure a for the matrix entries. its simple and clear.
for K matrix the steel column is fixed at the top and at the bottom.

if you load the steel column at different heights the maximal displacement is different. If the load is closer to the top, for example, you understand that the displacement at the loaded point is smaller.

Suppose you have any invertible matrix K, and you have its inverse.  The equation KK^-1=I can be broken down by individual columns of K^-1.  K times the first column of K^-1 gives you the first column of I, which is also how we're representing a discrete impulse at the topmost position.  K times the second column of K^-1 gives you the second column of I, which is how we represent a discrete impulse at the second discrete position.  And so on.  In other words, the columns of the inverse represent the response that this system would have to the columns of I, e.g. to discrete impulses placed at all of the possible locations.  Since the inverse is used to determine the response to ANY discrete vector, what this is saying is that you can decompose any discrete input into linear combinations of discrete impulses, and the response for that input will be the same linear combination of the columns of the inverse matrix.  This is linearity and the superposition principle.  To your second question, if instead of a 4x4 system we had a much large system, you would see that the diagonal entries in the middle of the matrix are larger, and they get smaller as you get to the top or bottom of the matrix.  K represents the fixed-fixed situation, so the endpoints are constrained.  Thus, if you put the load closer to one end, rather than in the middle, there is a limit to how much it can stretch the bar.  The stretch is maximum when you put the load in the middle. You could also pose yourself an interesting geometry problem: if you have two line segments, one starting at (0,0) and one ending at (1,0), and they meet at an intersection inside [0,1], and their slopes must differ by exactly 1, what location should the intersection have to maximize the height of the intersection?  The answer will be exactly at x=0.5.  Since the left slope is 1-a and the line runs until x=a, its height at its peak is a(1-a).  For what value of a is a(1-a) maximized?  The answer is a=0.5.
